newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares extend fall, seen down on Tuesday.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares extend fall, seen down on Tuesday.

text.p: Polish shares extended Thursday's fall, dropping 2.9 percent, and analysts saw another dip on Tuesday as the market fell in profit-taking after its recent 14.5-percent, six-session surge.
Analysts said some smaller investors may have been unnerved by the Dow's plunge on Friday when the Polish bourse was closed for a holiday but that current falls should prove restrained.
"It's a correction simply...turnovers are twice as low as they were a week ago," said Bogdan Kornacki, a trader at Wielkopolski Bank Kredytowy (WBK) brokerage.

The main market's all-share WIG index fell 2.9 percent to to 16,428.7 points and turnover eased 5.1 percent to 159.4 million zlotys ($45.9 million) on all three markets. Losers led gainers by 97 to six with 11 stocks flat.
Analysts said Polish shares still looked relatively cheap compared to neighbouring bourses such as Hungary's which saw sustained gains this year as Poland faltered.
But they said uncertainty in the run-up to the September 21 parliamentary elections and the exhausted surge by large-cap banks should limit the market's upside as well.
Large-cap stocks such as aluminium firm Kety, bank WBK and steel trader Stalexport fell sharply in profit-taking in light to moderate trade after recent surges.
Analysts said Monday's loss leader, metals trader Impexmetal down 9.9 percent in light trade, was hurt by Thursday's news of a significantly lower July net profit.
They said stocks could be affected on Tuesday by the release by most firms of July earnings data after Monday's session.
